From Martin Dougiamas (martin at moodle.com) Thursday,  12 September 2002, 07:23 PM:

My current plan for integrating this stuff into Moodle is as follows:



* Admin selects external source for usernames, and the source type (SOAP lookup, database table etc).  Can also choose what fields map to local fields (username and password are a minimum, but you might also want email, ID number etc)



* When user types in their username and password

 to log in), Moodle first checks it against the external source.



* If the username/password were correct, Moodle creates or updates a local entry in the user table, copying all the fields that were mapped on the source.



 * If the username didn't exist on the source then any local copy is also wiped and access is denied.



* Lastly, if the user attempts to change their username or password then Moodle forwards them to an admin-defined external URL to do it.

From Eloy Lafuente (stronk7 at moodle.org) Monday,  21 July 2003, 02:37 AM:

Ok. Here is an introduction to the backup/restore internals.



If you want to add a new field in the course structure to the utility, first of all you musk know where to do it. If the change is in a main table, you have to modify backup/backuplib.php and backup/restorelib.php. If the change is in a module related table, you have to modify backuplib.php and restorelib.php inside the module directory.



Second you must know what type of field you are going to add. If the field is just an attribute of the table and it is independent (not pointing to the primary key in another table, neither a 'serialized' field), simply add it in the backuplib.php with the rest of fields of the table) and add it in the restorelib.php (a bit more complicated, see below) with the rest of the fields of the table). For example, to add the 'visible' field in the course backup you must add a:



fwrite ($bf,full_tag(VISIBLE,3,false,$course->visible));



Where the rest of the course fields are written (in the 'backup_course_start' function).



To restore it, just add:



      case VISIBLE:

          $this->info->course_visible = $this->getContents();

          break;



In the 'endElementCourseHeader' function to read the value from XML and add:



$course->visible = addslashes($course_header->course_visible);



In the 'restore_create_new_course' to save the field to db.



The reason of this in that writing to XML is done in a one phase process, but reading and saving to db is done in two phases.



Restoring modules info is easier, because I use the 'infamous' xmlize function (memory eater!!) to read everything automatically from xml and there is only on required phase to save it to DB.



All of this is to add a simple, independent field. If the field points to another table or it's a complex field (the answer field in quiz_responses, for example) or it's a serialized field (the modinfo field in course) or it needs some validation, then the above guidelines are valid to backup but insufficient to restore. After restoring, it will be necessary to to some recoding or post process of the info, saving it to the temporary backup tables if it's going to be used after that). 



And this is the first introduction to the code. I hope you understand it (my English is really awful).



In the next post to this bug, I'll answer your a & b questions.



Ciao.

Summary: Implement a Key Authentication for Quiz (Deter Cheating)
Description:
One concern using online quizes in a live course is potential for abuse.  I think many administrations, especially, will voice this as a concern for course content.  



One idea I have had to address the issue is to require students to request a key from the instructor.  



The instructor could issue a key that will be required to open a quiz session.



Use of a key will at least provide an additional layer of authentication of the user, as well perhaps the ability to track other info for each quiz session.



The problem is not solvable technically, I believe.  Relying on an online session for voting, graded quizes, etc., necessarily rely on a level of trust of the user.  



However, maybe things like asking user to fill in some info would be helpful in deterring cheating.  Info such as: where are you taking this quiz, some personal information to use as a tag or or token, recording browser/IP info.



I'm not especially concerned with the cheating issue now, as I generally opt to trust students rather than not, and I've discounted the value of the quizes to minimize the impact of a potential cheater..



Thoughts?

Summary: pre-requisites for a course module
Description:
Here's yet another thought from the beardie idea factory.  Wasn't included in my mail the other day as it has just occurred to me.



Something that would petentially be useful in some courses would be the ability to set a pre-requisite for a course module.  Let me illustrate.



Say you have a course with five modules, numbered 1 to 5



The first module is the introductory section...fine...second module gets into the meat of the first part of the course and finishes with a quiz.  In order to gain access to the third module, the student has to get 70% or better in the final quiz in module 2.



The student gives it three attempts (which are of course tracked and the teacher may have already noticed this and stepped in to help) and the student eventually gets 75%.  This is enough to qualify...so his account gains a badge or token...as discussed in another bug entry the other day.  This badge says (effectively) course soandso module 2 pass.



Now module three has a prerequisite on it which says that participants must have that token or badge on their account to gain entry.  This student now has it, so he gets to move on to the next bit of the course.  Meanwhile, students who are not understanding the concepts in module 2 are prevented from progressing and getting lost in later things, before they have a decent grounding in the earlier stuff.



A quick check by teaching staff will show those that have not yet gained the module 2 pass token, so they know instantly who is having problems.



I know that it might be possible to do some of this by having a separate course for each module, with an enrolment key, and only issuing the next key to the student when they pass the quiz, but this would involve a lot more manual intervention by teaching staff that should be *teaching*...working with students, rather than dealing with fiddly admin stuff.  Also, how long would the enrolment key last?...by the time three people had passed the quiz, nearly all of the students would have the key...I know what students are like.



This is a pretty complex area of course...I don't even know if you agree with the basic concept, but having had a fair few years in this business (been in IT since 1984) dealing with user assessments and several years at OILP dealing with students, I know it would be a helpful facility for *some* subjects.

Summary: Quiz question results summary
Description:
I've had a request from some of the teachers here that I have demonstrating moodle to.



They want to know if the following could be added:



A way to press a button and be given a summary for any given quiz, showing the percentage of each question that has been answered correctly in all the attempts so far, and the percentage wrong (and I suppose by extension, if you have a question with multiple answers, each of which gains a mark, the percentage for each that was got all correct, or only part correct, if you see what I mean).



The reason for this request is so that, in a course in which there are potentially over three hundred students, it becomes possible to see, at a glance, which questions are being found particularly difficult by the student body as a whole.  Otherwise the staff would have to go into *each attempt* by *each student* and somehow build up manually a statistical analysis of the results.



This isn't a replacement for teachers looking at students' individual results...they will still do that, and check up on students that seem to be getting poor results on multiple attempts at quizzes, but it gives a useful way of gauging whether or not the quiz is being aimed in the right area, or if there is some deficiency in the teaching that needs to be corrected.



I guess there might be some way for me to hack together something by pulling the results data for each attempt out into a spreadsheet, but first I need to work out how each attempt's results are stored.

* Quiz pages (attempts and reviews) should appear on the printer as a faithful representation of what is on the screen. However, elements that are not relevant to printing (such as headers, footers, navigation blocks, submit buttons, edit buttons) should be removed in print.

* Print output should be available to teachers and students alike, at all stages of the quiz (e.g., with answered filled in or not).

22/Mar/12 3:23 PM;712020:ac10d74e-303d-4704-b1ec-b5a72f1d71f7;Thanks, Stuart, for reviving this *urgently* needed new feature. Yes, sticky forums/pinned topics have been batted around for ages, even before 2006 when this issue was first listed. I think it deserves a push again, because the core of Moodle has always been the forum,and Moodle has the best forums of any LMS. I am really proud of that and it is actually the reason I chose Moodle in 2003.

The reason we need pinned topics for an admin/teacher is because it aids in knowledge creation. Forums often suffer from an meandering, petering-out syndrome. That is OK in some cases, but sometimes the topic is so critical, that periodic summarizing and focusing can help, and literally *create* structured knowledge. I see two workflows in such a teaching scenario--one top down, one bottom up.
- Top-down pinned topic/sticky forum: the teacher or discussion moderator selects a main topic and pins it so it stays at the top of the list, and visually appears slightly emphasized (color or shading). As posts are added, the moderator grabs relevant content and summarizes what the group is learning from each other.
- Bottom-up pinned topic/sticky forum: Any forum that starts out in a normal, serial pattern, can be switched to a pinned topic mode. A person or persons can be selected or volunteer to summarize the discussion and keep that summary at the top of the discussion. Also, within a large forum, multiple pinned topics can be selected to rise to the top, either by moderator-choice or participant-voting. And of course, a pinned topic could serve as a directory within a large forum, where the key topics can be listed and visitors pointed towards them. 

Another reason we need pinned topics is because knowledge creation is extending beyond a single semester-single co-hort model. As we create learning communities that exist with ongoing purposes beyond merely granting credits for passing a course, we need to keep forums active and growing for many years, even after students graduate. Ways to capture the knowledge can include wiki, but a pinned topic is more organic, and can flow from the discussion. Moodle.org would greatly benefit from this, and give more specific roles for volunteers to help moderate some forums.

05/Dec/15 7:23 AM;712020:82a01497-88a1-46a2-bca9-c0f4e6c06361;Hi all,

I have spent some thoughts with [~accountid:712020:0ca3a761-806b-4d9e-b9ca-1e835a799f7b] on this feature request and we came up with a approach:

* We propose to create a solution which leverages the possibility of Moodle's rich-text editor as this will cover the clear majority of Moodle users. A quote feature for users who have disabled the rich-text-editor in the user profile (this includes the Plain Text, Markdown, Moodle Auto-Format formats) would be fundamentally different and is not covered by our project scope at the moment.
* Currently, Moodle ships with two rich-text editors: TinyMCE and Atto. We consider only Atto to be maintained in the long run and thus would like to focus on Atto.
* Summing up, our approach would provide a nice quote feature for users using Atto (which is the default for new Moodle instances anyway) without impeding other users.

* We propose to create a solution which will feel like modern email quoting as this is what user's expect from a quote feature.
* We would probably create a combination of an Atto plugin and a modification of mod_forum:
** The mod_forum modification will be needed to provide a "Quote" button besides the "Reply" button in the forum discussion and to paste the quoted post's content into the Atto editor on the following page. It would wrap the original message in a div with a class with suitable styling (e.g. left-hand border + padding). 
** The Atto plugin will have to handle the styling of the quote and the management of replies which are inserted into the quote like it's possible with every today's email client (handling cases like to split the div at the point when the 'enter' key was pressed, adding a non-styled section in between).
* Based on that functionality, it would make sense if the Atto plugin can also be used detached from the use case at hand as a quote-styling button (especially as MDL-48905 and MDL-45662 to implement blockquotes in Atto seem not to come to an end).

This makes sense to me in theory.

I would propose creating subtasks of this issue and splitting it into logical components:
# add a way to "reply with quote" when replying to the post; and
# changes to blockquote editing in atto.

With the reply with quote component, I have a few concerns, namely the fact that you can currently already reply to a forum post. I'm concerned with the prospect of adding an additional action to the post and how that would be presented. A couple of thoughts on potential solutions:
# we make this a per-user preference
** (/) no additional UI component within the forum UI
** (x) we have too many such preferences
** (x) this doesn't give enough granularity - it's either on or off for a user, and you can't choose it on a per-post option
# we add a "quote" link or similar which performs the reply + quote action
** (/) simple and hopefully clear
** (x) UI clutter
# we incorporate this change into an inline editor change
** (/) puts everything into the same place
** (/) keeps everything in context
** (x) not really part of this request and would still need an option to include the reply but may provide different options for doing so

I don't really have a suggestion for how to solve this, and I think we'd need to see some mockups and ideally to involve the UX team ([~accountid:70121:c9656886-f14e-41ea-a644-42f5e9822a23], [~accountid:70121:0b3e79d4-1b90-4573-b67e-6313412088a4]).

We should really use the standard HTML blockquote when creating the quoted text, so I don't know exactly what changes would be made in Atto and I think this is likely to be the area of most critique in this issue. You'd need to go into a bit more detail on how you'd anticipate this working, especially for those adding multi-line block quotes. I guess you're looking for something like Jira when dealing with markdown - e.g. if you are in a list, and press return, you continue in the last. If you press return again, it exits the list.

Hope this helps,

Andrew

Summary: log archive option for log maintenance
Description:
I like the ability to delete logs, but what would work better for my installation would be the option to archive logs older than a certain date.



We absolutely have to be able to look at old logs to be able to confirm attendance records, but it is very rare that we need to look at anything older than a few months back.



I'm thinking that the best way to do this is to create another table log_archive, that is identical in structure to log, other than id not being autoincrement.



The archive process would go like: check for old records in log, do a REPLACE query for each old record into log_archive.  Delete the copied record from log (or do a single delete query that deletes all records from log with an exact match in log_archive).



Any page that lets you look at activity logs would have a button added that you could check to look at archived logs instead of current logs, or possibly to look at the current and archived logs.  If the site had been configured to delete rather than archive records, the option to view the archived records wouldn't show up.

When looking up logs, allow the search to specify starting month/year and ending month/year so that only the appropriate log tables are included in the query.

Summary: Moving Interal Text Processing, Locale Catalogs, etc. to UTF8
Description:
As moodle user base expands and more languages become supported (hooray!), the value of reliance on uniform (standard) API's for text processing becomes more apparent.



Currently, there are problems in mixing locale data encoded in different codesets, because Moodle does not implement logic to first tag and process to a uniform format.  



Because user and host systems continue to rely on a variety of codesets for encoding of (other than vanilla ASCII) text, moodle interally should use Unicode for all text processing functions require all locale input be sanity checked/converted to an acceptable unicode format.



UTF8 provides a variety of benefits and is currently well supported on most user and host systems.  This feature request urges reliance on all UTF8 to address the concerns discussed above.



The UTF8 support provided by PHP should be confirmed and appropriate tagging and conversion routines developed to provide user upgrades to a new UTF8 architecture.  Database backend issues may also emerge where assumptions on the backend DB might conflict.  Eg. although mysql and postgres both support UTF8 default codesets are configurable for both, and installation scripts for database creation should be looked at to set the appropriate default codesets at installation.  For upgrades, there maybe some more complicated solutions required to sanititize backend data to UTF8.
Comments: 18/Jul/06 5:51 AM;557058:04670d95-8ea4-4705-9d43-683a4fdf2d81;From Martin Dougiamas (martin at moodle.com) Thursday, 3 July 2003, 09:20 PM: Good stuff, yes, it would be nice to have this consistent. It looks like a bit of work, though, with many possible platform issues. http://au.php.net/manual/en/function.utf8-encode.php From Martin Dougiamas (martin at moodle.com) Thursday, 3 July 2003, 09:23 PM: Also see: http://au2.php.net/mbstring From James Miller (yositune at yahoo.com) Monday, 7 July 2003, 12:25 AM: Interesting. I looked at the links. It's not a trivial matter and conversion from traditional codesets to UNICODE don't always go both ways. I think the ideal would be all Moodle data stored locally as UTF8, with a flag for user's preferred codesets (default to UTF8), and conversion from UTF8 to the user's codeset where feasible. Because of what Unicode is you can't always go from UTF8 to codeset foo (as I recal). So might not be feasible for all languages. For example, Japanese, Korean, and Chinese (there are others..) all use Chinese characters to one degree or another. However, the characters do not always look exactly the same and Unicode glyphs usually opt for display as one languages style. Summary: Cookie as aid for quiz cheating detterance
Description:
It would be nice to have cookies which might warn an instructor if multiple users are doing a test from the same machine. That would help prevent students from doing quizes for friends, and in the even of a password being hacked, from using that password to do random trial and error quiz responses. This happened to me last term.  



Okay so students could edit the cookie but, while students can various things to cheat on quizes (or practices as I prefer to say), and there is no way at the end of the day that one can stop them if they are realy determined. But one can make it difficult.
Comments:
24/Aug/06 1:24 PM;712020:6373ec6e-2a10-4a86-9493-052782609013;I got a "work has stopped" message on this one too. "Work stopped" may mean nothing, but even so I will take this opportunity to comment some more. 

When I posted the above I did not know what I meant.

While there are some online survey systems that provide the option to actually block test attempts from multiple users on the same machine, I don't think that many teachers would want to do this. I would not. 

However the ability to show which attempts where made from a the same machine would be nice. 

Another way of doing this would be to show the IP address of the attempt. And that would be nice too. 

However there are many situations where multiple machines share IP addresses. Uur computer labs all have the same IP address I think. 

If a cookie method were used, it would show where people have logged off as one user and then logged on again as another user, even while there is a cookie for the other user left on the machine. 

Students could delete all cookies and circumvent this check. But a lot of them would not know to do so. So the ability to keep track of both IP address and (this bug) "attempt from machine which also has cookie for user X" (?) would add information to help instructors maintain an awareness of possible cheating. 

Obviously, just because multiple attempts were made from the same machine/environment does not proove that the students who made them were cheating, but if the attempts were particularly similar, and the students (or a subset of them) are getting noticably higher marks in tests than they are in class, then, well evidence adds up. 

Tim

24/Aug/06 1:50 PM;557058:5188c7d7-5671-48d1-b501-6c3ae2b91f34;I'm afraid I don't agree with this bug at all.

For a start IP address is a very vague way of identifying anything, and cookies are no better.

In Moodle, we have a proper authentication system: people log in with usernames and passwords. If students are abusing the system and you have people logging on with each other's accounts, then you have serious problems that go way beyond the quiz module. In fact, it is a disciplinary problem that can probably only be soved outside Moodle.

However, if you are suspicious about certain behavior, then there are the Moodle logs, which do record what everyone has been doing on the site (including which IP address they are doing it from). As I say, the problem extends beyond the quiz module, so the central logs are the correct place to try to tackle this.

If the interface for searching the logs isn't good enough, that is a separate issue. The the quiz module does not add good enough entries to the logs for some actions, then that is also a separate issue.

Therefore, marking this one wontfix.

24/Aug/06 2:26 PM;712020:6373ec6e-2a10-4a86-9493-052782609013;Good morning. I am not sure of the meaning of "Won't fix." Does this only refer to your own kind endeavour Tim? Or will the Won't fix label affect the efforst of other programmers?

I am aware of the authentication system in Moodle. In my recent comment, I am not talking about the scenario where students are sharing the same Moodle account, but different accounts on the same machine (or environment), in the cookie cache of which, there are cookies for other accounts. E.g. if I were to log off on this machine and attempt to log on again as another user, I think that Moodle would know that there is a moodle cookie for the original user on the machine. 

I am also aware that moodle logs IP addresses but the logs do not record multiple cookies in the sense described above. 

In my experience it is only on the testing modules answer sharing becomes a problem. 

The interface to search the logs could be improved so that one could search for users of a certain module....Hmm...I am not sure why this is more of a logs issue. 

It is possible to go from the quiz results page to the logs and cross reference between the two to see if similar test responses were submitted from the same IP adress but it is very hard if there has been a lot of other use, by other users at the same time. 

In order for the logs to provide the information regarding possible quiz answer sharing, the logs would also have to display the responses and scores (and their similarity). 

I agree that both cookies and IP address are vague ways of indentify things but I believe that they are usefull additional information in the hands of the earnest teacher. This reminds me of the claim that javascript prevention of copying is similarly vague (or insecure) and therefore of no use. It is in fact tremendously useful, because it stops some people from cheating. Similarly information about cookies woudl stop some students from cheating. This information would add up.

25/Aug/06 12:14 AM;557058:5188c7d7-5671-48d1-b501-6c3ae2b91f34;'Won't fix' means that I as module owner think that it is not a good idea to implement the feature suggestion. I always think that phrase sounds rather abrut and rude, but it's the one that all bug trackers seem to use.

What you are asking for is a way to detect possible cheating. I am convinced that a cookie is not going to help there. The best way to detect this is to look at the results that were actually entered by each student. If there is evidence of copying there, that is the strongest evidence there could be. Automatic plagiarism detection is a subject in its own right, and not one I know very much about. It would be a great project to give a bright university student one summer (perhaps next year's google Summer of Code?). They could implement a new quiz report pugin that compared answers from different students to look for possible cheating. It could even combine some data from the logs too if that turned out to be effective.

And securlty is not solvable just with technology. You need to think of the whole picture. As a comparison what do you do with paper tests? If it is an important test, you probably don't let your students take it away and do it in their own time when they can copy from each other or books. Instead you call it an exam, and insist that they do it with an invigilator watching them to make sure they don't cheat.

25/Aug/06 1:22 AM;712020:6373ec6e-2a10-4a86-9493-052782609013;I respect your opinion. I can only hope that as you suggest there are others that may be interested in supplying the relevant code. 

For my own part, I realise that I could use an invigilator, but alas that would eat into class time in which I prefer to use for communication. Thus, the central focus of online testing is for me, how to make it as secure as possible. To that end, praise be your module, 
Random ordering of questions and answers
Random banks of question variations
Quiz timing
Javascript making coping more difficult
IP address logging 
User authentication (at least in terms of passwords)
provided by the Moodle quiz module at present, are a way of moving invigilation out of the classroom. Of course security will never be complete, but as the layers of security provisions build up, Moodle provides a method of testing that could never have been achieved with pencil and paper homework tests. At my school there is an even more foul attempt to use pencil and paper tests. The course which I run, using moodle, is doing a lot better I believe. It could work a lot better still.

04/May/16 3:07 AM;557058:c1816d26-9b59-4fca-9dfd-09d5e132d03d;hi Mike,

The plugin is throttled so it has near constant light load and processes the url queue slowly over many cron ticks. You can also schedule the crawler task to only run at certain hours via the task admin gui if you want. In the crawler config are two items for tuning the throttling depending on your cron setup if needed but the defaults are fine.

To test just a single course wasn't really something we designed if for but you could sort of coble it together something like:

a) only give the robot user access to and visibility of that one course (maybe a custom role)
b) set the seed url to that course page (can be set in the admin gui local_linkchecker_robot | seedurl of forced in config.php)
c) let it run to completion either via cron or run the crawler cli in a loop outside the normal cron
d) give the lecturer the results, probably exporting is in some way
e) run the reset cli and rinse and repeat.

There are quite a few caveats with this, 
1) pretty manual, no self serve
2) only one course can be checked at a time (or you could add the robot to X courses and run them as a batch, but not sure how to seed them, would depend on front page or category access to the courses)
3) the reports are only around until you reset it
4) there currently isn't a way to export the results (I've added this to the todo list)

So you could do it, but don't think it's worth the bother and would be clunky. I think it would be better to just use it as-is OR alternatively we'd implement a new feature where a lecturer can self service and add their course to a list of seed urls, it's get processed in the next crawl session. Then their course seed url drops off and the current course reports function as they do now. If you want to sponsor that send me a PM

Comments: 24/Aug/06 9:47 PM;557058:15b6744c-43dd-4f3f-bc2e-13573f92f0fd;assign to a valid user

26/Oct/07 6:32 PM;712020:00374572-278c-4c0f-8edd-0536e94eef7f;I discovered a simple solution: extend the time of editing.  Do the following:

1. Open moodle/administration/settings/security.html in suitable editor.  I used Dreamweaver 4.0.

2. Revise last line of the array as follows:

get_string('configmaxeditingtime','admin'), 2700,
             array(60 => get_string('numminutes', '', 1),
                   300 => get_string('numminutes', '', 5),
                   900 => get_string('numminutes', '', 15),
                   1800 => get_string('numminutes', '', 30),
                   2700 => get_string('numminutes', '', 45),
                   7257600 => get_string('numminutes', '', 120960))));

Note: I chose 7257600 seconds (=120960 minutes) because this equals 12 weeks.  Any suitable time period can be chosen. 

3. Save and PUT security.html into moodle files using a ftp transfer.

4. Open up your Moodle sites and log on as "Administrator."  Go to the Site Administration/Security/Site Policies.  Find the "Maximum time to edit posts" and select "120960" within the drop-down selection box.  Go to the bottom of the page and "Save Changes."

Having done this, participants can now edit their posts for 12 weeks.  At the Catherine of Siena Virtual College, classes can run up to 10 weeks. The extra two weeks enables participants to edit/delete their material during the two weeks following the end of class. From that point onward, materials become the property of the College and can be used to promote the course for forthcoming participants/students.  For details, see http://www.catherinecollege.net/moodle/mod/resource/view.php?id=139

Aaron

From Gustav Delius (gwd2 at york.ac.uk) Monday, 9 February 2004, 04:08 PM:

Well, in that case they should have been called html filters, shouldn't they? :-)

 

TeX is a non-XML standard. It's been around since the sixties, after all. Any replacement of symbols inside a TeX equation will break it immediately. So a TeX filter certainly has to run before any other filter.



The way around this is to have a universal filter as part of format_text that passes everything inside start tag - end tag pairs through a registered filter.



One way to implement this would be to have a table mdl_filters with fields 'id', 'start tag', 'end tag', 'filter', where 'filter' somehow specifies the filter to be applied (for example by giving the name of the subdirectory of the filter directory where it can be found).



The current mechanism for calling textfilters would then only be used for filters that aren't triggered by tags, like the glossary filter for example.



This is now definitely something for 1.3. However there is no 1.3 in the Version box in this bug tracker. I will post this message in the textfilter thread as well because someone else may have a good idea.

My personal feeling is that we _cannot_, and _should not_ attempt to support a true anonymity type feature. Suggesting that Moodle is truly capable of this is a dangerous statement as Moodle is not able to influence things like server logging as I've discussed before.

Although it is possible to obfuscate the user when they post by associating the post with a false user record, it _cannot_ be described as having been `{{totally anonymously}}` posted. Unless I'm very much mistaken, this places you in the same place that you are in now - course logs are enabled, an administrator can determine the true identity, but a standard teacher cannot.

If you are trying to support the `{{strong privacy is required by law}}` requirement you mention, I would strongly advise that you do not claim this unless you have disabled all user logging, including at the network, and the web server levels. Best wishes,

Andrew

My current implementation is adding a new disguiseid field to the context table. Although this approach works, the limitation is that it is very difficult to determine inheritance from other contexts without giving some values special meaning, or simply ignoring them.

Our proposed alternate solution was to instead use a new table (context_disguises or similar) and create a manager class (core_disguise in lib/classes/disguise.php I propose) to handle fetching of the disguises. I can't quite recall what we decided about how a disguise would, or would not, apply within an inheritance. I think the idea was:
# if a disguise is applied at a parent context, a new disguise cannot be applied to any child context;
# where a child context already has a disguise, that item can be modified, but not enabled/disabled (because the user identities would change).

There is still a lot of work to be done here, namely:

25/Feb/16 7:35 PM;5b04c63b88b6744fe4207a9b;Hi all,

I'm going to put this issue up for peer review today to get some feedback on the way in which I have implemented this at a core level.

This change been implemented as per the [specification I posted last year|https://docs.google.com/document/d/1z6LSKlNj0OD-1V6xL-CmRvQ6weG-6MwPXmszaU5vO14/edit] and is close to feature completion.

As previously discussed I have renamed this feature to 'User disguises' to reflect the true nature of it and the fact that true anonymity is close to impossible.

h5. State
Disguises has been architected as a plugin-based design where disguise plugins dictate:
* how display names are calculated for display;
* the URL used for the profile page (if one is set at all);
* the URL used for the user_picture (if one is set at all); and
* the URL used for user messagign (if one is set at all).

The original feature request here was for mod_forum to support anonymity, but I felt early on in the design stage that this functionality really should be available to other areas too. Given the pedagogical use-cases for this feature, I feel that it is potentially suited for any interaction between students (e.g. mod_chat, mod_wiki, mod_workshop, block_comments). As a result disguises are implemented directly within the context.

h5. Features
The following features have been implemented:
# Ability to select from a range of disguise types (new plugin type)
# Ability to enable/disable the disguise entirely
# Ability to determine which users can see the true identity of disguised users:
## Teachers, Editing teachers, and Managers (by default) have a capability which will allow them to reveal identity if the disguise has been configured to reveal identity to some users.
## Manager (by default) has a capability to reveal identites at any time.
# Ability to reveal true identities from a specific time/date
# Support for 'anonymous' logging of the events system
# Plugin archtecture with two plugins
# Hooked into navigation/settings navigation
# Hook into $PAGE to ensure that the current user is configured (and allow redirect to a plugin-specific configuration page).
# Works in Moodle Mobile application with minimal change required in the app
# Applied to mod_forum
# May be applied to any module
# Ability for a disguise configuration to be 'locked' so that disguise revelation settings cannot be altered. This can be unlocked by the administrator (capability based).

h6. Plugins
I have created two plugins at this time:
# disguise_basic: Teacher defines a single value which is used for all users. No profile links, message links, or user pictures are displayed
# disguise_predefined: Teacher defines a set of possible names which are allocated randomly on a first-come, first-served basis. No profile links, message links, or user pictures are displayed.

I would like to create some additional plugins, but these will probably happen after this issue is integrated:
# disguise_userdefined: User may choose their own pseudonym. No profile links, or message links. User may choose a custom user picture.
# disguise_role: Teacher defines a set of roles, similar to disguise_predefined. Custom profile links (to support role backstories). Teacher may define a custom user picture.

h5. Performance
Because they are implemented at \context, and all uses of the context SQL helpers have been updated accordingly, there should be no increase in the number of DB reads when a disguise is disabled.

Additionally the disguise is loaded into the context so subsequent calls to {{$context->disguise}} will not increase operations significantly.

When a disguise is _enabled_ there will be one additional DB read to fetch the disguise configuration, and then additional reads (and potentially writes) may be required depending on the disguise in question.

In the plugins I have written:
* disguise_basic should not cause any additional DB reads or writes as all configuration is held within the disguise itself.
* disguise_predefined will lead to one additional DB read to fetch the disguise mappings for all defined names, and one write per user as the disguise is first applied.

h5. Outstanding items
Although the feature is near completion, there are still a few outstanding issues to resolve:
# Improve $OUTPUT->user_picture() to allow specification of custom URLs
This will allow disguises to have custom pictures for each disguise - potentially very useful for role play situations.
# Standardise user picture display in mobile app In some parts of the mobile app the user picture URL is manually calculated using the userid and the userpicture. This happens in the forum and needs to be updated for the previous item to work in the mobile app.
# Finish the admin UI for disguise_predefined

I'll be starting on these soon

## All disguises need to backup both their configuration, and their data
## We need to consider as to whether it should be possible to back up a disguised context if the disguise is locked and the user performing the backup cannot reveal identities.

Summary: Post / review document module
Description:
This is about a way of reviewing / commenting on a document.



I tried using a web application last year, for discussion and document review, but stopped when it was blocked by our company firewall which blocks discussion board time sites with dire warnings...



The site is quicktopic.com they provide a free instant discussion area and a free document review system.  



This looks like a commercial venture however the document review system has some good ideas in it:



Firstly, it is possible to upload a document prepared offline. 

Documents are then split into sentences and a discussion list is associated with the document, with an entry available for each sentence.

At the start of the sentence there is an add comment icon, which allows users to add comments about the sentence.  If comments exist then it is possible to view them and add further comments.  Typically a comment could be used to suggest an alternate sentence or provide advice / feedback.

Lastly it is possible to view the document with the comments expanded in-line.



My Proposal:



What I am suggesting here is a module that allows someone to create/post a document.

After it is submitted, it is formatted / split into sentences with the option to allow the addition of comments on a per sentence basis. (These could be from tutors and / or students).  

If comments exist then an  icon or link appears by the sentence. 

Tutors comments could be private / in another colour.

Comments could then be viewed by the student, either individually or as view of the document with the comments embedded.  (Export/download would be useful).



Because this is based on commenting on a document, then the best way of incorporating the comments in a new version would be to upload a revised draft for a fresh set of comments to be made.

e.g.  one student would have the role of editor to incorporate the comments in the new revised draft.



If there is interest in this, then I can put together a more detailed specification /design  for someone to code.



Roger

23/Nov/06 6:02 PM;712020:fa6e41d7-a4db-4444-adda-e7bc5e35c3fa;Here's a summary I wrote:

Moodle iCalendar export summary

There are many cases where it would be useful for a user to be able to export events from their calendar in Moodle into a separate calendar program such as Evolution or Kontact. Many such programs also support subscribing to a remote calendar feed, in which case the program automatically downloads the latest version of the calendar at regular intervals.

The standard format for calender information is iCalendar, as defined by RFC 2445 (http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc2445.html). This format is supported in varying degrees by Korganiser/Kontact, Evolution, Mozilla Calendar, Apple iCal, Google Calendar and Microsoft Outlook.

I have implemented support for Moodle to export calendars to iCalendar format, in such a way that subscription is possible as well as download. This support is based on a partial implementation by Jon Papaioannou, using his Bennu (http://bennu.sourceforge.net/) library.

This can be accessed by two links at the bottom of the calendar page (calendar/view.php). 'Quick download / subscribe to calendar' links straight to download all events (global events, user events for the logged-in user and course events for relevant courses) from the last 5 or next 60 days. The URL includes the username and does not require logging in in the usual manner, so that it can be subscribed to with calendar applications, which are of course unable to handle the usual login process. Instead, a reasonable measure of security is provided by the 'authtoken' parameter in the URL, which is a SHA-1 hash of the username concatenated with the password hash. The use of a hash means that should someone else get hold of the URL they cannot discover the user's password. The use of both username and password in generating the hash avoids the problem of discovering users with the same password. This basic approach was suggested by Martin Dougiamas in the forum thread at http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=37393.

The 'Export calendar' link on the calendar page leads to a page where more options can be configured. The user can then either click 'Export' to download the calendar, or 'Get calendar URL' to be given the appropriate URL (generated by JavaScript) to copy to their calendar program to subscribe.

This form is handled by calendar/export.php and calendar/export_basic.php. The actual export process is handled by calendar/export_execute.php, with the help of Bennu.

I have tested the exported file in Korganiser/Kontact, Evolution, Outlook, Google Calendar and Mozilla Calendar and it seems to work in all 5, though Mozilla Calendar doesn't handle the timezone quite right.

Summary: user installation and php-cgiwrap
Description:
This is a feature request, noticed because this is how I have my server set up and how I tried to set up moodle and found that I could not set it up.  The way I tried to set up moodle was by creating a moodle user on a Unix system and install the moodle files in the moodle user's public_html directory.  In order to comply with my php-cgiwrap installation I need to put all *.php files in ~/public_html/php and mirror the entire directory path to those files in ~/public_html.  Other files, (images and html templates) then are in the irrored portion under ~/public_html.  When a URL is called, such as: http://mydomain.org/~moodle/index.php, the php-cgiwrap installation, by virtue of the .php extension and the AddHandler rule in Apache's httpd.conf file for handling .php files, the request is directed through php-cgiwrap which looks the ~/public_html/php directory for the script.



In moodle, I set up my config variable:



$CFG->dirroot   = '/home/moodle/public_html/php';



to reflect this installation which works for loading the main index.php page during installation, but when that page looks for header.html, it looks in /home/moodle/public_html/php/theme/standard for the file, which is incorrect because it really lives in /home/moddle/public_html/theme/standard.  I could, of course, install the whole of moodle under ~/public_html/php, but the server can't server things out of the http://mydomain.org/~moodle/php directory.



A user installation withough php-cgiwrap would probably work okay, but I have not tried it.



Although there are considerations already made for suexec, I think php-cgiwrap support would be useful as well.  In some other docmentation on the moodle.org site regarding suexec support it was chosen over php-cgiwrap because of tighter security and that it doesn't allow reading of directories and writing of scripts, but this doesn't make sense because the point of php-cgiwrap is that scripts won't work unless they are permissioned with 0700.  



I think that php-cgiwrap support in moodle would also be valuable to Solaris administrators, some BSD users, HP-UX users, and some Linux users as it adds extra control and security over your user's doings, which is what big installation Unix admins like.



The URL provided is to my installation of moodle under php-cgiwrap how I would have liked to have set it up.  It may not remain up but please contact me about getting it working, I can probably help.

Summary: Forum dross removal
Description:
Some discussions and replies are ephemeral. Others are keepers. Suggestion: auto-hide or auto-kill stale posts. Newcomers to a forum have an easier time ploughing through.

1) HIDING: For automatic dross removal, add required-entry drop-down box above Submit button to self-set an expiration date. Writer chooses, say, from hide in 10/20/30... days, delete in 10/20/30... days or sticky. Applies to both new topic and replies. Thus writer self-moderates to summarize the forum for the longer term. Admin sets the default for the drop-down null choice. 

2) A soft Delete could flag record as permanent-hide from all viewers except admin and writer, who can edit anytime to upgrade as hide or sticky.

2) DISPLAY: Readers viewing Forum toggle hide as a filter for viewing only the most enduring postings (or unhide if they really want to troll through everything not set to the permanent-hide.)

3) STICKY: (no-hide, no-autodelete) if the post has lasting value into the future. A sticky reply forces its discussion topic to no-hide during display. Admin and original writer can edit a sticky to downgrade to hide or kill.

4) CREAM: For the cream-of-the-cream posts, let Admin set a cream (super-sticky) option that causes an icon to be displayed during page-view to advise future readers of valuable content worth reading first.

5) GUI - Add one drop-down box as above. Add Edit Status option link alongside the Reply link for original writer and admin.  

6) DATABASE - two more small-integer fields per discussion or reply. First set to 0,1,2,3 for cream,sticky,hide,kill. Second gives number of days since posting-date for hide or kill. 

7) CRON not needed for the soft-delete (permanent-hide) variety since all records remain intact. Display or not is filtered during the page view.

I had for quite a time felt that this was a significant shortfall in the forum module, which most particularly shows up in the General Problems forum where it is quite plain to most regular contributors that new users are completely shocked and overwhelmed by the email storm that results from their first post, such that they hurriedly switch of their subscription to the forum and never get to see the responses they may have had! 

It is almost equally a problem if you unsubscribe and just keep a browser tab open and refresh it periodically - if you have answered half-a-dozen queries, then within a few days you can have forgotten which titles/users you replied to (would I EVER write that down?), they become so spaced out in the list, you may never get to see that you were asked a follow-up question! This is a less than fabulous situation.

However, instead of complaining, I have, as I have posted in moodle.org forum and the Forum module forum, done something about it.

I am posting up a patch (originally on 1.9.3) that implements subscription by discussion thread (discussion <=> thread here). Tim Hunt will I hope, in due course, check the patch to make sure I have got that part right - I believe so!

To work this patch you need an extra column in the table (mdl_)forum_subscriptions, so you must first run the sql statement:

ALTER TABLE `mdl_forum_subscriptions` ADD COLUMN `thread` BIGINT(10) UNSIGNED NOT NULL DEFAULT 0 AFTER `forum`, ADD INDEX `mdl_forusubs_thr_ix` (`thread`);

I have also left off a tiny (and non-critical) bit from theme/standard/styles_layout.css...

#mod-forum-discuss .subscription {
float: right;
text-align:right;
white-space: nowrap;
}

But for the rest - the changes in 11 files - are in the patch.

I have annotated all changes, and you can search to find each marked by the initials JWC (later we will of course want to remove such egotism!!)

I have tested it as thoroughly as I can - it is implemented on a training site in the UK, and I've got a team of people roped in to comment on it, but I am very open to suggestions for improvements. I can think of one myself: on a big site you might appreciate a check box to 'show me discussions I'm subscribed to' on the forum page, or even 'show subscribed discussions first' to alter the listing order!

I too agree that this could all seem a bit overwhelming to course leader and to users. For that reason I have tried to keep the options as simple as possible and to give useful (but brief) information in the help. In short I have given three extra options for the forum itself, and what the user can see is based on which of these is chosen:

4. Allow thread or forum subscriptions
5. Automatic thread-based subscriptions
6. Force thread-based subscriptions

I'm sure there needs to be a debate about these settings to. You need to consider, particularly, what effect each would have if the teacher subscribes all course users to a the forum, when the default setting is one of the above. This issue has been considered and I hope you will appreciate the subtlety of the results.

Regards,
John

02/Feb/09 6:27 AM;712020:ce9a094b-875b-43da-a148-f85d28e81e35;I thought I would add a little about what it is you are meant to see with this patch...

Obviously in the Forum settings panel the teacher/administrator has 3 extra options in the 'Force everyone to be subscribed?' drop-down.
4. Allow thread or forum subscriptions
5. Automatic thread-based subscriptions
6. Force thread-based subscriptions

Also in the Forum page itself the t/a sees an extra fast link 'Automatic thread-based subscriptions' (if not already chosen), below 'Force everyone to be subscribed'.
- This seems to be to be the most likely option to want.

When option 4 is chosen 'This forum allows everyone to choose whether to subscribe or not' appears as a reminder to all users.
With option 5 the text is 'This forum provides thread-based subscriptions automatically'
and with option 6 the text is 'This forum forces thread-based subscriptions'

With either option 4 or 5 all users (with a subscribable role) see an extra column in the discussion list: 'Thread subscribed?'
This contains yes/no buttons for instant thread subscription.
Neither option stops the user from subscribing to the entire forum.

Switch to option 6 and these buttons become yes/no text only, because you can only be subscribed to a thread by posting in it (this state does not recurse backwards to posts you have already made if the forum settings are changed).

None of these settings stops the t/a from subscribing users to the forum, such that they appear in the forum subscribers list (which is unchanged), but if this is done the 'Thread subscribed?' column disappears as it is irrelevant!

With options 4 or 5 the user can unsubscribe from the forum (because that is not forced) and then the yes/no thread subscription buttons appear, though if you move from forum-subscribed to forum-not-subscribed, all the buttons will be in the No state, and the user can change any.
[Note: It could be argued that for state 5 these should all default to Yes, see below.]

In state 4 or 5 you also get a fast link for 'Subscribe to this discussion thread' or 'Unsubscribe form this discussion thread' on the discussion page, 
and 2 extra options in the 'Subscription' drop-down on the posting page:
'Send me email copies of posts to this discussion', and
'I don't want email copies of posts to this discussion'.

The difference between these to states is that whereas in state 4, the user's profile setting for autosubscribe is used to pre-load this 'subscription' setting,
in state 5 it is always pre-loaded to 'Send me email copies of posts to this discussion'.
So state 5 is automatic, not forced!.

In state 6 this option box disappears, as do the fast links and buttons for subscribing and unsubscribing.
In place you find that the user is subscribed to any thread they post in.

But what if all students have been pre-subscribed to the forum by the t/a with thread subscriptions in state 6?
Then the user receives mail from all threads until he/she posts to a discussion (new or old), then their forum subscription drops out and they are subscribed to the newly posted thread only.
The principle of this one is that whereas the teacher may wish to hail all course participants with the merits of their forum, NOT removing the forum subscription would render it the same as Option 1 'Yes, forever'!!!

The result of all of this is that mdl_forum_subscriptions now keeps track of who is subscribed and to what forum/thread. The value thread=0 means the whole forum, which is why this must be the default setting for column 'thread' so as to keep all existing subscriptions intact.

Then the cron has an additional task to do. As well as collecting all forum subscribers, it must collect all thread subscribers but it must do so in such a way that the user profile data is collected only once for all cases; and this it does.
Then a very small change to the condition that allows emails to be generated is all that is required.

So far my tests appear good, but I have to admit to two untested areas, 
1. Does read-tracking upset this regimen - I think that unlikely, and
2. What happens where groups are used for subscriptions.

On these, or any other matters, I am keen to receive feedback.

Regards,
John

Technical:
In order for the buttons to run most efficiently (and compactly) when AJAX is enabled, each button holds only minimal information (the threadid and subscribe or not), the forumid is held in the overarching 'ajaxform' form which calls to 'yesno.php' or 'yesno_ajax.php'. 
But without AJAX enabled each button becomes its own mini form, because it contains all the data including the forumid (wasteful, but I think necessary - especially if we have to provide for the no Javascript in the browser case).
However, I left the overarching ajaxform form in place (in this scenario its redundant), and this messes up the straight href call in the FIRST button ONLY (I presume that it reacts to the nearest </form> tag, not being happy with the fact that these forms are nested).

Fix:
In mod/forum/lib.php, 
in function forum_print_latest_discussions(...), 
the start and end of the form are wrapped by the AJAX enabled condition:

Thus...
About line 5347:
	if (!empty($CFG->forum_ajaxrating)) {
		echo '<form id="ajaxform" method="post" action="yesno.php">';
		echo '<input type="hidden" id="forumid" name="forumid" value="'.$forum->id.'">';
	}



About line 5537:
	if (!empty($CFG->forum_ajaxrating)) {
		echo '</form>';
	}


Now all four scenarios work, for ALL buttons:
AJAX enabled at server; Javascript enabled in browser
AJAX enabled at server; Javascript disabled in browser
AJAX disabled at server; Javascript enabled in browser
AJAX disabled at server; Javascript disabled in browser

I will post an amended patch shortly.

On a very general note: cache event invalidation can be a risky thing with older parts of Moodle. I'm not sure how forum stands truthfully, but normally before going down this road I would strongly suggest only invalidating by events from API's. All interaction with something through an API passes through a single point somewhere in the process which is where you would trigger your invalidation. Without the API you may find that its impossible to be sure you trigger the invalidation in all places, especially for older code like forum where it was originally acceptable to assume forum was present and interact with them in other code (obviously not the case now).

In regards to the singleton idea what I said to Andrew could be summarised by saying it is just a matter of time and effort.
I agree that if time wasn't an issue a better approach would be to look at singleton class for the core forum concepts and supporting static helper classes for bulk actions.
However I believe we are trying to get forum improvements achieved within sprints and refrain from significant modification and Petr'esq rewriting of the Forum at this stage.
The inconsistency between forumid and forum caught my eye while reviewing this as well, however when I followed back the methods I understood why Andrew has done what he has done.
It may not be the perfect approach but that in my mind would be a serious investment, and what has been done is at least logical.
On the plus side when Forum finally does get some serious loving, or a replacement is found it should be easy to map these methods to the new structures.
By no means is my answer definitive, but the current approach gets a +1 from me.

Cheers
Sam

We could separate interface language and content(=course data) encoding.



I would propose moodle_convert($string, $src_ecoding, $trg_encoding, $hints). Of course we also need number and date formatting functions, it should not be a problem to create it in pure PHP.



There is a problem with string functions, iconv is incomplete - seems to me mbstring is the only way.

-----------------------------------

YES:

NO:

Summary: Integrating Jabber/XMPP
Description:
I read on the Moodle forums that there was interest in Jabber support in Moodle and that it is even planned. My suggestion is to work together with the ejabberd project to reach this.



Why ejabberd?

As it's easy to install (Winbows binary available, included in REPOS: http://www.erlang-projects.org/Public/news/erlang_repos_beta_7/view ) and to administrate via a webinterface I believe it is quite suitable for IT people in schools. Besides that other nice things (for schools) of ejabberd could be:

* nearly XMPP compliance

* many features out-of-the-box like Publish-Subscribe (most of them in modules)

* support for LDAP authentification (which is used a lot in schools/universities AFAIK)

* support for xml:lang (this means the webinterface, disco nodes, and other parts can be translated): currently available languages are de, en, es, fr, nl, ru and uk.

* stable



ps: I selected Component All, as you can do many more cool things with Jabber/XMPP.

Summary: Add possibility for instantaneous feedback
Description:
What I would like to see:

The _possibility_ to have instantaneous feedback in moodle.  This would physically manifest in:



1) having a course-level option to have extended feedback

1.1) adding an 'instantfeedback' column to the quiz_answers table in the database



if 1) is selected:



2) during question entry, there would be two feedback fields where there is now one.  This would require changing the question types to handle this.  This perhaps only makes sense for multiple-choice, true-false and numerical type questions.  The current question types would of course continue to function whether or not they are modified.



if 2) is implemented for a question type:

3) during quiz taking, the student could be presented with this instantaneous feedback.



Instantaneous feedback?!  What's that???

Currently, feedback is given in Moodle only after the student has submitted the quiz.  Instantaneous feedback would provide a sort of coaching for the student while he/she is taking the quiz. For example: when the student clicks on an incorrect answer, he/she is immediately given feedback  (e.g. 'No, not that one, try again' - or something more useful in the context of the quiz).  This would require javascript to handle the feedback - or the use of an alternate question presentation, for example using flash.

Summary: Multiple course categories
Description:
A functionality that would allow adding a course to multiple categories.



Detailed description of problem and feature below:



At start I would like to write, that it is nice to be here, thanks for possibility to use Moodle as an excellent e-learning tool. You all did a great job.



I think I have one suggestion for Moodle. I am not sure if someone already wrote few words about it, sorry in case of I am doubling the topic. Let me explain the problem.



As a school of higher education we do have various types of studies. For example We offer to our students three-year bachelor courses, two-year supplementary master courses, five-year uniform master courses or postgraduate courses. Additionally some of those types can be realized in full-time or part-time. Now about subjects - some of subjects (which are courses on Moodle) do fall under all types of courses, some do not. And we do have years.. one subject can be taught in the first year of full-time studies and third year of part-time studies. One more thing.. we do have various majors.



So as You can see we do have a lot of categories one Moodle course should fall under. Now I can assign a course to one category only and I do not really know how to solve my problem. One solution is to name courses using a particular schema and use description field to add information about who is recipient of the course. Another solution is to create for example 4 copies of one course and assign it to few main categories.. but then a teacher will have to publish a new document in four courses. Hmm.. those solutions are still a half-solutions and seems that in the nearest future those can couse a lot of additional problems.



I think many other schools will have to face (or already did?) this problem. What do You think about the problem ? Is it important ?



Finally, how about adding such functionality to Moodle ? A functionality that would allow to assign a course to multiple categories (and a course can still remain in one category only). 



From my point of view it seems rather easy, but probably it is not. Some interfaces should be changed allowing to assign course to multiple categories and database structure should be changed too by adding new table which stores data about courseIDs and categoryIDs.



Dear Martin Dougiamas what do You think ?



with best regards,

Tomasz Jankowski

Summary: Course-wide activity date modification page
Description:
When copying an existing course to a new time frame (such as a new semester), each activity's start and stop dates must be manually adjusted, which can become quite tedious for a course with many activities. This patch will provide course admins with a unified page which groups together activities by date. Adjustments can be made individually or by groupings, either by relative date adjustments (days, hours, and minutes) or by absolut date adjustments. Since most activities which share a common date are most likely to continue to share a common date after rolling over to a new time period, it makes the most sense to sort all activities into similar date groups so they can be updated at one time.

Some screenshots and discussion can be found here.

The technical issues, now...



First of all, we need to better define pinning. Pinning My Courses would be straightforward, but what if you pin an instance of a block which allows multiple, like HTML? I 'm going to ignore this problem for the time being.



The pinned status should probably go into mdl_block_instance because otherwise it will result in code I really wouldn't like... you know, bad things happening. That table has pagetype and blockid for each instance, so it shouldn't be a problem to update the pinned flags whenever we need.



It follows that pinning stuff can very easily be made to affect only those pages it should; we simply update the pages with pagetype equal to that of the page where the admin does the pinning.



New pages... well, we could so something like:

SELECT DISTINCT blockid FROM mdl_block_instance WHERE pagetype = 'newpagetype' AND pinned = 1



Then we could compare the results with the blocks we were going to add anyway and cook it up before we start making any instances for our new page. I can't see any problems, this can also respect each blocks applicable_formats with no trouble.



What about the admin pinning a block in a page, which doesn't exist in some other page of that type (let's say the teacher has deleted it)?



Well, we can do:

SELECT DISTINCT pageid FROM mdl_block_instance WHERE pagetype = 'newpagetype' AND blockid = 'pinnedblockid'



(this gives all page ids where this block already exists), then:



SELECT DISTINCT pageid FROM mdl_block_instance WHERE pagetype = 'newpagetype'



(this gives all pages of that type). Now we can array_diff those two arrays and find the pages where the block being pinned does NOT exist.



Then, add a bunch of records (one instance of the block in each page, at the default new block position, with default block config). This wouldn't require updating existing instances, as we 'll be adding the new instance at the end.



Finally, proceed with pinning all necessary instances as described above.



The good part is that this would only mean modifying blocklib (which encapsulates everything), the clients (i.e. pages) don't need to know anything about pinning.



Of course it's probably best if we only do this in 1.5, in 1.4 it would be quite hard if not impossible to do this seamlessly.



Satisfactory?

From Jon Papaioannou (pj at moodle.org) Friday,  11 February 2005, 09:28 AM:

About how to handle multiple instances and pinning:



This occured to me while thinking about my previous reply. Incidentally, I 'd be against the pageid = 0 for pinned stuff solution not only because of yuk, but also because that's pretty restrictive (you can't pin more than one kind of each block in a page).



OK, so, how to handle pinning blocks with multiple instances:



The key concept here is that multiple instances === different configuration for each instance. With this in mind, we have to address the following issues:



1. If an admin pins a fully configured and working RSS client in his My Moodle, what do we do for all students? After all, they may have their own pet RSS clients in their My Moodles.



2. Let's say we have solved issue 1. Then, some sunny day the admin reconfigures his RSS client. How do we know what other instances of that block to update? Shouldn't the pinned RSS clients in My Moodle also reflect this change for everyone?



The pinned column idea comes back with a vengeance:



1. For non-multi blocks, this would result in checking which My Moodles don't have that block. But if you pin a block with multiple configuration, we have to assume that you want an EXACT COPY of this to appear in everyone's page. Therefore, it's not unreasonable to assume that NOONE has this exact copy already in his page (and if they have, it doesn't matter much anyway). So, start by taking for granted that we will add an instance to all pages with the same pagetype. The configdata for those instances will be of course a copy of the configdata for the instance which is being pinned. And we 'll set their pinned column to 1. So far so good.



2. The trick here is to think that we don't HAVE to set pinned to 1! In fact, any non-zero value will do, because that's mainly going to be used for if($instance->pinned) checks. So, actually don't set it to 1, but set it to the instance id of the original block pinned by the admin! This way, each pinned instance will hold the information of which instance was the original pinned prototype. Now updating the configuration of the pinned prototype is going to be a breeze:



UPDATE mdl_block_instance SET configdata = '...' WHERE pinned = '$instance->id'



3. A final detail: we need to know that each prototype instance has been pinned, of course. Thus we need to set their pinned column to somewhat other than 0. Cool; just set it equal to their instance id. That takes care of detecting that it's pinned, and also gives us the way to know if a specific pinned instance is the prototype or a clone: ($instance->id === $instance->pinned) only for prototypes.



While I 'm very happy with the elegance of this approach, reconfiguring the prototype of a pinned instance is going to get you an update with maybe 27K rows affected. I don't know if that's hard on the db though; I imagine that it really shouldn't be. Certainly, nothing compared to 27K queries with 1 affected row each.



Feedback?

Martin's proposal was to put the info into the course->modinfo by letting each group-aware module return an extra property $info->usesgroups in its modulename_get_coursemodule_info() function. This would then be built into the modinfo cache by the function get_array_of_activities. This would work but the drawback is that the modinfo cache would grow. The information on whether a module is groups-aware would be duplicated for each instance of the module.



The most straightforward option would be to store the information in an extra field in the modules table. Its drawback is that it allows only one setting for all resource types. If some resource types implement groups but others don't then this won't work.





Another scheme would be to simply set course_modules->groupmode to -1 if the module does not support groups. This could easily be done but the drawback is that when the module then becomes group-aware the developer might forget to set the groupmode for existing coursemodules back to the course default. Perhaps not really a problem, after all the developer will quickly notice the problem. I think I like this option.

Simple but should meet the needs of many people.

hmm... I am not entirely sure what should be done here. I guess some members of the backend team would have more valuable information, I will ping them.

The main issue with changing the definition of an event, is not only causing troubles for existing observers who specifically need to be updated (as you said, no backwards compatibility, but also overhead for plugin developers), but more importantly, as the data of the events is used for logging inconsistencies would be generated. Let's say you are a logger, but you discard the information _objecttable_ (and you should because it is hardcoded within the event), at some point the _objectid_ changes because _objecttable_ has changed in core. Now, all the logging information you have suffers inconsistencies and you do not have any way to recover from it.

I think an event definition should never change, but I agree that in this situation it is a bit tricky. Another option is to trigger the same event for each answer provided, that might not be ideal, but that provides flat data and follows the logic that was in place previously.

Fred

The only other way I can think of to keep the event handling consistent with the existing functionality would be to do some horrible de-normalised database structure where we would store all a user's answers in a single row, but I'd be reluctant to do that just to maintain backwards compatibility for events. I suspect it would also result in a more complex patch, as with the multiple row structure a lot of the existing functionality continues to work without any need for patching, but I don't think this would be the case if we used a de-normalised structure.

Hopefully the backend team will be able to come up with some ideas!

Martin, you may be looking at this from wrong angle. 



The problem with list headers is that they are not consistently used/implemented and they do not help to visually see which forum the message belongs unless I really filter the posts (all headers are hidden in mail client). I post and subscribe (and get dropped after a while) to different forums, depending what issues I am facing. I am fairly active now being new to Moodle but this will fizzle away once all works. The volume of mail from each forum is not big enough to go through the trouble of setting a new mailbox and filters (and remember to delete them when dropped from forum not to slow down filtering). I rather have all Moodle posts go into a single mailbox and then use Eudora's concatenator (not same as threading and I find it more useful -- on many lists I am on, people start new thread by replying to older post, granted not the issue for Moodle since it does not accept email posts, but Moodle is only one of many things I do and I am too busy to develop new habits just for Moodle while retaining other modes of operation otherwise; I doubt I am unique in that respect). 



What I am suggesting that the GUI for setting up a forum allows me to enter an email prefix as an optional item. This is stored in db in the record defining the forum. When mail is being sent, the script checks whether custom prefix is set. When yes, this prefix is used. When not, the prefix is set as it is now. I believe this should not be a difficult modification or have any side effects.



Currently, it seems that the course name not forum name is used as prefix. I gather this is because different courses are likely to have forums of the same name (like the default news forum created for each course). This is logical except its deficiency when a course has multiple forums. The solution could be to use both course name and forum name, but then the prefix can be unwieldy long. Allowing custom prefix solves all IMHO by giving control to site administrators and teachers. It would surely allow me to handle them gracefully at my site: I will have 120-150 courses per semester with students typically taking 4-6 in parallel. We set up all courses with minimum of 2 forums, each with the same name for all courses, one being teacher announcements and another open forum for participants (so it makes a difference to students which post comes from which forum and which course). Some teachers set up additional forums for specific projects.



I do not see how any generic (fixed) approach can be universally useful in this case. Your current approach worked fine for Moodle being used by individual teachers or tight operations but now that it is spreading into enterprise-level use, you need to allow more control.
