Summary: Reforming random questions
Description:
During the rush to get the new quiz module ready for Moodle 1.5 Eloy, Julian and I had valuable discussions about how to reform the handling of random questions. In the end we decided that for Moodle 1.5 we would have to go back to a model that uses the same response storage as Moodle 1.4 because otherwise the upgrade and restore scripts would become too complicated to write and test in the available time. However we do want to make changes for Moodle 1.6.



I am posting an email exchange with Eloy on this here so that it gets preserved until we get time to deal with it again.



Here is my proposal for how to deal with random questions.



A random question will not be a question type. It will simply be a

randomly chosen question. So an attempt will only consists of ordinary

questions. Some of them, it is true, are randomly chosen when the

attempt is started, but there is no reason why the attempt has to

worry about that any more. Similarly responses are always responses to

ordinary questions, so no random question type will show up in the

states table.



Only the quiz has to know that some of its questions are to be

randomly chosen. So we need to decide on some mechanism to store that

information. I propose something very simple: The field

$quiz->questions will, as currently, be a comma separated list of

things. These things can be:

1) a number corresponding to the id of a question,

2) a zero indicating a page break,

3) the letter c followed by a number indicating the id of a category

from which a question is to be randomly chosen

4) the letter r followed by a number indicating the id of a category.

A random question is to be randomly chosen from this category and all

its subcategories.



There are only three places in the code that need to be changed:

1) the editing page. I can do this quite easily (I wrote most of it)

and the code will actually become simpler.

2) the function quiz_create_attempt() when creating $attempt->layout

will replace the c.. and r.. things by randomly chosen questions.

3) the upgrade code



What we gain by this is that we can get rid of the whole hidden random

question type.



The old model where the information about which question was chosen

was stored in the response table seems outright wacky. This is not

information about the response but about the attempt and should

therefore be stored in the quiz_attempts table. My proposal achieves

that.



The upgrade should not be too bad because the responses to the actual

questions were already stored correctly in the past. We only have to

get rid of the dummy responses that are actually pointing to the

questions and put this information into $attempt->layout instead.





And here is Eloy's reply:



your plans sounds pretty well, although I'm not 100% sure if such

change should be done just now.



Although the change seems really simple, just a change in the encoding

of quiz->questions and inside quiz_create_attempt(), it would involve

updating tons of quizzes under Moodle's servers, looking for every

random question used and their real counterparts for each existing

attempt to be able to personalize each attempt->layout field.



And, talking about pre15 restore code, it will imply to rebuild the

attempt->layout field AFTER their states has been restored (to be able

to extract each real question used) and after it, delete all those

random responses from states.



Doesn't it sound complex? At least for me, yes. Anyway, perhaps I'm a

bit paranoid but, at current development stage, adding such IMPORTANT

change in a question (and the overall module) sounds really dangerous

(potentially, I know).



Finally, if the objective is to avoid using the states->answer field

to  store attempt-definition information, we have another question

type using such field to store attempt info. It's the RANDOMSAMATCH

qtype. It stores what shortanswers questions has used. Being strict,

we should change the quiz->questions and attempt->layout fields to be

able to encode such info correctly and then, in states, only standard

shortanwer responses should be present.

Summary: custom/extension language packs
Description:
Moodle could go one little step further with support for personalizing, localizing, and/or extending language files. If I create a new language, for example en_local, to replace a few of the standard strings or to add an extra string, then this language shows up as 'English (en_local)' in the language popup menu. Not very professional and potentially confusing to some users. I'd like to use en_local as language but still have 'English (en)' in the menu. Our users do not care whether the texts are localized or not.

Moodle could designate the _local locale suffix as having a special meaning: designating a language customization. It'd automatically strip this suffix from the language code when building the popup menu (or simply use the parentlanguage string). This would also make such language folders easily identifiable as not part of the distribution.

I believe this would also make it easier to add extra strings for a given site, which is particularly useful for true multilingual sites, offering an alternative to multilang filter for fixed web page elements. I suspect that using a custom language pack is more efficient than multilang filter.

Summary: Course-wide date management utility
Description:
When copying an existing course to a new time frame (such as a new semester), each activity's start and stop dates must be manually adjusted, which can become quite tedious for a course with many activities.  This patch will provide course admins with a unified page which groups together activities by date.  Adjustments can be made individually or by groupings, either by relative date adjustments (days, hours, and minutes) or by absolut date adjustments.  Since most activities which share a common date are most likely to continue to share a common date after rolling over to a new time period, it makes the most sense to sort all activities into similar date groups so they can be updated at one time.



Some screenshots and discussion can be found at http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=9697.

Summary: Separate 'Link to a file or web site' into two items
Description:
Replace 'Link to a file or web site' with



Link to a file

Link to a web page 



The latter I suggest to refer to web page not web site since that is what the links are. Even using a generic site address, we really link to their default page.



I found that a number of our instructors are somehow confused by the dual function of the 'Link to a file or web site' resource. I understand that under the hood they nicely share the same code, but I submit to present them to users as two different resources. 



They are in fact different. One refers a file that had to be uploaded to local server, so it is functionally similar to 'display directory'. Another refers to a web page somewhere in the world. 



This split would allow for improved verification of input (cf MDL-3558) and adding control of the icons (bug 3338).



The file resource could display file size and last update date in parallel to what display a directory resource does. This is often important to students (since files are often updated in the course of semester) but instructors notoriously forget to add it manually.

Summary: $menu in header does too many things
Description:
The $menu variable in the themes header.html does too many things.



On the front page of your Moodle it tells you who you are logged in as as well as allowing you to choose a language (as long as that option is switched on)



On Course index pages it only tells you if you are logged in.



On Resource pages it gives you a button for viewing logs (again, only if switched on), a jump menu, and a previous and next button.



All of these things are pretty cool, but it's a bit of straightjacket that you can only specify them to be in one place and, by extension surround them with a single bit of HTML and CSS style.



You may well want all of the above to appear but in different places and styled differently. Or you may only want some elements e.g. the jump menu without the backwards and forwards arrows.

From David Scotson (d.scotson at admin.gla.ac.uk) Friday,  22 July 2005, 10:23 PM:

I've rolled back the previous code I added and followed Martin's suggestion above i.e. there is now code in gdlib.php that will resize the f1.png image a little bit bigger, cropping the border or (if the resize function is not available through GD) it will color the border based on it's inner neighbour pixels.



I tested on a variety of userpictures from Moodle.org and the results are fairly equal between the two methods (the resize loses an extra 2 pixels from the image and introduces a slight fuzz, the interpolation picks up some slight muddiness around the edges on solid-colour, pale backgrounds because of JPG artifacts in the orignals) so it might be best to choose between them based entirely on speed. The resize is doing much more work, but it's doing it through GD so it's anyone's guess as to which is faster without doing some experiments.



There's a testpage at userpix/upgrade.php that lets an admin run the upgrade function on all current userpixs to see the effect and roughly how long it takes (this is a permanent change so only try it on backups or test machines). Bear in mind that the resize code will zoom further and further in if you run it repeatedly (the interpolation code won't).

From Jon Papaioannou (pj at moodle.org) Wednesday, 7 September 2005, 03:15 AM:

I just recalled that this problem was caused by an incorrect $CFG->wwwroot setting in config.php.



Everyone affected, can you please triple check that your $CFG->wwwroot appears EXACTLY AS IT IS DEFINED as a prefix in your Moodle installation's URLs? In other words, is your Moodle index page's URL EXACTLY THE SAME as your $CFG->wwwroot (except from a slash at the end)?



From Jon Papaioannou (pj at moodle.org) Thursday, 8 September 2005, 11:41 PM:

After having an email conversation with Chris Davis who also had this problem, we can conclude that:



1. The error is caused by an incorrect $CFG->wwwroot setting.



2. $CFG->wwwroot should be a fully qualified URL (prefix) and not a partial (relative) URL.



This is GOOD: http://some.hosting.net/moodlesite



This is BAD:  /moodlesite



3. If for some reason you need your wwwroot to have one of several possible values depending on some factor (e.g. if the person accessing Moodle is inside or outside a particular firewall), the correct solution is this:



Instead of using a partially qualified URL, put some elementary logic (if/else statements) in your config.php file to select one wwwroot value depending on some parameter (e.g. $SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR'] or $SERVER['HTTP_HOST']) and make sure that all of these possible values are fully qualified URLs.



Chris solved this problem for his installation by changing



$CFG->wwwroot = /class;



to



$CFG->wwwroot = http://.$_SERVER[HTTP_HOST]./class;









Bug closed.

From Bram Luyten (bluyten at gmail.com) Thursday,  18 May 2006, 04:42 PM:

There have been some issues with the dirty workaround that I suggested before.



They relate to the behaviour of the me() function in weblib.php



For some reason (probably webserver related), $_SERVER['REQUEST_URI'] returns a FAULTY url with multiple / instead of one /



you can try out if this is the case at your setup by including 

echo $_SERVER['REQUEST_URI']; somewhere.



We got a final fix by changing the following in the me() function in weblib.php



$darn = $_SERVER['REQUEST_URI'];

$test = str_replace (//, /, $darn);

return $test;



instead of

return $_SERVER['REQUEST_URI'];



Together with the previous dirty workaround that I suggested, this should work.

A note about the scoring (for when the documentation needs writing up):
* All positive scores for this question type are scaled to add up to a total of 100% 
** e.g. if there are 4 'correct' answers (marked with '=') and none of them have percentages specified, then they are each worth +25%
** if there are 4 'correct' answers and one has a percentage of +50% and the rest have no percentage specified, then they will be scaled to +14.3% for one and +28.6% for the other 3 (so the +50% has half the weighting of the others, which default to +100%)
** if there are 4 'correct' answers, and they are given percentages of +50%, +50%, +25%, +25%, then the final percentages will be: +33.3%, +33.3%, +16.7%, +16.7%
* If no percentages are specified at all, then all incorrect answers are given a score of -100% / (number of correct answers).
* Reasoning behind these rules:
** If no percentages are specified (just correct answers marked with '='), then ticking all correct answers will give a total of 100% and each incorrect answer ticked will exactly cancel out 1 correct answer
** If any percentages are specified (for the subquestion), then the scoring switches into an 'advanced' mode, whereby negative scores need to be given specifically (if left out, then the incorrect answer will have a score of 0%, which means it will not affect the final grade, whether ticked or unticked)
** It is annoying to have to always make sure that the positive scores add up to 100% - as they always must add up to this total (otherwise the question gives a fatal error), it is much easier for the computer to handle the scaling, after the teacher has specified any relative weighting of the right answers (if required).

Summary: Ability to specify maximum number of responses in multiple choice
Description:
In the quiz module, it is possible to specify that a multiple-choice question has either 1 correct answer, or else more than one.  This then determines if radio buttons or tick boxes are used for the answer selection.



However, consider the scenario where there are a number of questions that have four possible responses, only two of which are correct.



You assign 50% of the mark to each correct answer, and assign no mark at all to the incorrect answers.



Enter smart-alec student, who selects *all* of the possible responses for each question, and thus achieves a 100% mark on his first attempt without actually knowing anything.



Now it *is* possible to assign a negative mark to the incorrect responses to try and discourage the above behaviour, but some of the teachers don't like this because it interferes with them being able to see easily what the total mark was for correct answers.



Would it be possible to modify the quiz module so that, when a MCQ is created, that has more than one correct answer, the teacher creating the question can specify the maxmum number of responses allowed for that question?



In the above example, that would mean that of the four possible responses, a maximum of two could be selected.



I realise that this would probably involve some more javascript, in order to make the interface nice, which would make the thing less accessible than it should be.



Or perhaps the number of responses on each question could be checked before final submission, and the submission rejected if any question has more than the permitted number of responses?



I hope I've managed to make this clear and haven't just rambled.



What do you think, Gustav?





Sean K

There needs to be some rationale for determining what is an advanced option. How do default values for advanced options get set? At what level should those settings be implemented (site, course, user)? Ideally I would like to see some type of interface where by the system administrator can determine whether a particular field is considered advanced or basic and define a default value. Further refining may involve providing the ability to set a context for that particular default. That would mean that for courses created in one particular context the system admin could set a default value for a particular course setting (say the enrollment key and make it advanced) and set an different default enrollment key for another category. Similarly, for a particular user, the admin could make an particular option basic so that it appears for them because they use it frequently but for the rest of the users make it advanced. Of course I realize implementing this would add an additional level of abstraction but it would put the system admin in control of the user's experience. I think ti could be debated whether this would ultimately improve or complicate usability since each user could have a different experience. But I think this would be worth discussing among the users (or at least initially among the developers). Peace - Anthony

Summary: Additive Forum post scoring
Description:
Currently if forum posts are numerically rated, the forum grade is the average score of all a student's rated posts.  For example, if a forum is worth 10 pts and a student post is rated at 9 and then the same student posts again and it is rated at 3, the student grade is 6 -- students can lose points for additional posting.



An optional Additive option would allow the score to be the sum of all the student's rated posts, limited to the max value set for the forum (recalc if forum scale is changed to different max value).



This would also allow for rating each post 1 for those who simply want a count, though Count could also be an addtional rating type and would be automatic if selected, without putting anything in (or altering) the rating field.



Yet another possible rating type would be Highest (to take an analogy from quiz scoring).



Ideally none of these would affect the individual ratings, just the score that is sent to the gradebook.

Summary: Course template
Description:
In reality, there are 3 different things:



   1) subjects (e.g. Informatics for beginners, Macroeconomics etc.)

   2) concrete classes (e.g. Macroeconomics on Tuesday, teached by Mr. XY in classroom 26B with these 20 students, Macroeconomics on Wednesday, teached by Mrs. YZ in classroom 115A with another 20 students)

   3) groups (e.g. project groups, each group has 5 students)



You have subjects, classes and groups but Moodle implements just classes (courses in Moodle's terminology) and groups. This has some implications to course management - currently it's quite hard to create many concrete classes of one subject that share some common learning materials, polls, surveys etc. One proposed solution is to backup and restore one course to another but then you have troubles when you need to change something in all courses.



How to deal with this problem? My suggestion is to create some course template. It would be a normal course with resources, surveys and other activities, but without teachers and students. From this template, you'd create concrete courses with two options:



   1. linked copy option, which means that every update in the template course would also update every derived course, and

   2. hard copy option, which means that updates to the template course has no impact on the derived concrete course



For more information, see these two discussion topics:

http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=29025

http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=28994

As an alternative, I suppose a pagination scheme could be used, but often I just want to do a search on a relatively unique ID, and make the matching user a creator.

Summary: Make the manual grading report work with random questions that pick manually graded questions
Description:
Encountered a problem for grading Essay Questions.

To reproduce the problem:
0. Edit the essay question type so that the method is_usable_by_random returns true.
1. Add a random question to a quiz and select category X for the random question.
2. In category X only have Essay Question(s)
3. Take the quiz as a student.
4. Go to the Manual Grading Tab as a Teacher and you will find that there are no essay questions to grade.

This is because of how the code checks for essay questions in the quiz.  Go to line 256 in grading.php to see how it does this.

The random question type causes a lot of problems for grading Essay Questions because if the random question is pulling from Essays and non-essays then not every student will answer the question.

So, the method for how the grading code looks for essay questions in a quiz and the interface for grading essay questions need to be altered.  I'm not entirely sure how random questions work so I am stuck on this problem at the present time.

Another solution is to add ESSAY to the excludedtypes array in random question type.

Looking at Paulo's patch, it basically adds an OR clause to the SQL to find random questions in categories that contain essay questions. 

What it fails to take into account are random questions that pick from a category and all the child categories (this is indicated by questiontext='1' for the random question), and where the essay questions are in the child categories, not the to level category. Summary: Add support for media-specific stylesheets in themes
Description:
After discussion with Urs, we came up with a scheme for adding media support.



If we add this to config.php in the themes:



   $THEME->mediasheets['handheld'] = array(...);

   $THEME->mediasheets['screen'] = array(...);



etc 



and if mediasheets is defined, then add an additional stylesheet link to a composite stylesheet which will be CSS just for that media type.



In addition, we should add the parameter 



    media=all



to the existing stylesheets that we already have.  This is assumed anyway but it's nice to make it explicit.

13/Aug/13 10:33 AM;5d5f788c3aee330d4323c9d0;Another alternative could be to use the alternate name fields that are being introduced in Moodle 2.6.

* Go to [Administration  Site administration  Language  Language customisation] and choose the language that you want to change (English) and open the language pack for editing.
* Select moodle.php and type 'alternatename' in the string identifier.
* Change the local customisation to 'title' or something similar and save your changes.
Now go and set up the name display to use the new 'title' field.
* Go to [Administration  Site administration  Users  Permissions  User policies] and scroll down to full name format.
* Change the format to "alternatename lastname".
* Now have the teachers fill out the "title" field in their own individual user settings.

*Now all teachers will be shown as "Mr Smith" or "Mrs Jones"*

h5. Behat
# We usually add a user story-like description after the feature name. For example:
{noformat}
Feature: A cool feature
  In order to XX
  As an editing teacher
  I need to be able to YY
{noformat}

h5. Message provider
# "{{MESSAGE_DEFAULT_LOGGEDIN}}" and "{{MESSAGE_DEFAULT_LOGGEDOFF}}" are deprecated. Please replace these with "{{MESSAGE_DEFAULT_ENABLED}}" instead.
# Do we need to define message providers for each enrol plugin? I think we can move this up (e.g. to core). Then all enrol plugins can simply provide the ability to send enrolment confirmation messages.
# "{{messagenotificationconfirmation}}" is quite a vague name. Perhaps something like "enrol_confirmation" or "enrol_confirmation_notification" would be more appropriate.
# No need for a period at the end of the language string "Confirmation that message notification has been sent." Additionally, it also seems vague. Perhaps something like "{{Confirmation that the user has been enrolled on a course}}" would be more suitable?

h5. Enrol method form

h5. Language
# The [enrol/welcometocourse and enrol/welcometocoursetext|https://github.com/moodle/moodle/compare/master...marcghaly:master_MDL-4188#diff-22560272441044f05379cbd0c9547d907f6dce56e760d21b1bc28b6ad8bbf669R171-R176] are marked as deprecated (Placed under the "Deprecated since xx" section of the lang string file) )when they are being used as the default message. Summary: Remove popups
Description:
I believe popups are the wrong way to interact with the user. I know this would entail a lot of work to implement, but please consider this for future revisions of Moodle.

07/Sep/15 9:51 AM;712020:5c12bbd5-33f1-4b98-a58f-8a9c4a9dcbf9;I too would like to have a late penalty feature in Moodle quizzes. Late penalties are a good way to help students keep up with the pace of the course and are used in universities around the world.

Here is my workaround which I will explain with an example. Bear in mind that this is only a workaround until a late penalty feature is implemented in Moodle.

Although my workaround is somewhat laborious to set up, the result is simple to use by the students. The method uses only standard features of Moodle and does not require any manager permission. Also, it can be modified easily as required.

Let us assume that quiz.MQ is due on September 10th, 5:00 pm (where MQ stands for Moodle quiz). Late penalties are as follows:

    on time = no penalty
    late within 48 h = 10 % off
    late within 7 days = 30 % off
    late more than 7 days = 50 % off

These penalties define four time periods, for which four late penalty quizzes are defined: quiz.LP0, quiz.LP1, quiz.LP2 and quiz.LP3 (where LP stands for late penalty). These quizzes are placed conveniently below quiz.MQ on the Moodle page. Depending on the lateness, the corresponding late penalty quiz will appear when quiz.MQ is completed.

The late penalty quizzes consists of one Short answer question asking for the students initials, with the wildcard * as the correct answer. Hence, any answer is correct and it is simple to get one of the following marks depending on lateness:

    full mark for quiz.LP0:   100 points (= 100  0 penalty) 
    full mark for quiz.LP1:   90 points (= 100  10 % penalty) 
    full mark for quiz.LP2:   70 points (= 100  30 % penalty) 
    full mark for quiz.LP3:   50 points (= 100  50 % penalty)

In the gradebook, define quiz.WLP as a grade item. This is the grade for quiz.MQ with the late penalty taken into account (WLP stands for "with late penalty taken into account"). In Categories and items of Grade administration, define the formula for quiz.WLP as:

=[[quiz.MQ]]*max([[quiz.LP0]];[[quiz.LP1]];[[quiz.LP2]];[[quiz.LP3]])/100

where quiz.MQ, quiz.LP0, quiz.LP1, quiz.LP2 and quiz.LP3 are ID numbers.

Add the following restrictions under Restricting access in quiz.LP0 to .LP3. Hide all the conditions (cross the eye) :

    quiz.LP0
     The student must satisfy all the following conditions:
        o Date: until 10th September, 17:00
        o Grade: quiz.MQ leaving % blank
        o Grade: quiz.WLP < 1 %

    quiz.LP1
     The student must satisfy all the following conditions:
        o Date: from 10th September, 17:00
        o Date: until 12th September, 17:00
        o Grade: quiz.MQ leaving % blank
        o Grade: quiz.WLP < 1 %

    quiz.LP2
     The student must satisfy all the following conditions:
        o Date: from 12th September, 17:00
        o Date: until 17th September, 17:00
        o Grade: quiz.MQ leaving % blank
        o Grade: quiz.WLP < 1 %

    quiz.LP3
     The student must satisfy all the following conditions:
        o Date: from 17th September, 17:00
        o Grade: quiz.MQ leaving % blank
        o Grade: quiz_1.WLP < 1 %

where:

 quiz.MQ leaving % blank insures that the proper quiz.LP0 to .LP3 will appear only when quiz.MQ has been completed.

 quiz.WLP < 1 % means that quiz.WLP is still 0 % where it is assumed that students cannot get a mark < 1% for a completed quiz.MQ. This will display quiz.LP0, quiz.LP1, quiz.LP2 or quiz.LP3 as long as it is not completed and will hide it once it is completed (with a brief message saying that it is no longer available).

Give the same label to quiz.LP0, quiz.LP1, quiz.LP2 and quiz.LP3 such as Please confirm with your initials and give corresponding feedbacks such as You have submitted on time, A late penalty of 10 % will be applied, A late penalty of 30 % will be applied and A late penalty of 50 % will be applied.

If a student is late but has a valid justification and should not penalized, his mark for quiz.LP1, .LP2, or .LP3 can easily be changed to 100 in the gradebook in order to cancel the penalty.

When setting up the workaround, be careful to define Grade items before defining restrictions referring to them. Also, Gradebook formulas containing undefined ID numbers will almost crash the gradebook but it can be corrected and nothing gets lost.

The workaround can easily be extended to the case where the same deadline and late penalties apply to a series of quizzes. It is slightly more complicated to set up, but works fine.

I have tried this workaround with my students and so far it works quite well.

16/Dec/20 1:26 AM;712020:ce48121a-6a0e-4e2d-927e-52f1170d8d93;Thanks Dominique for posting the work around. I've modified it slightly and thought I'd share (sorry this is my first ever post so please let me know if I've committed a faux pas).

I have the original assignment (quiz.MQ0), copies of the original assignment (quiz.MQ1, quiz.MQ2), and an extension request "assignment" (quiz.extension). I would like to penalize 10% per week extension (can be easily adjusted to different values).

+Extension "assignment"+

The quiz.extension assignment contains one multiple choice question, where the possible responses are the various requested extension times, e.g.

a) One week extension ("correct" - 100%)

b) Two week extension ("partial credit" - 90%)

I then set quiz.extension to have a total point value of 100, thus if a student requests a two week extension, quiz.extension will return a score of 90; I'll use the score of quiz.extension to be the penalty for the extension.

+Restriction setting:+
 * quiz.MQ0 has a *grade* restriction that student+must not+ have a grade for quiz.extension. This ensures that the original assignment is hidden if an extension is requested to avoid the student attempting to complete the "wrong" assignment.
 * quiz.extension has a *date* restriction that it will be visible after the quiz.MQ due date has passed. This ensures that an extension cannot inadvertently be requested prior to the original assignment closing.
 * quiz.MQ1 has a *grade* restriction of quiz.extension must be >= 90% and a close dateof the original due date + 1 week.
 * quiz.MQ2 has a *grade* restriction of quiz.extension must be >=80% and <90% and a close dateof the original due date + 2 weeks.

The last two restrictions ensure that only one extension assignment is visible. Also helpful is that the close date can be modified using the Reports > Dates whereas the*date* restriction has to be modified by going into each assignment. The former approach is my preference as I often run behind in lecture and therefore need to change due dates.

+Gradebook setting+

In the gradebook, I then created a new grade item (quiz.WLP). I then used applied the calculation to the grade item:

=if([[quiz.extension]], max([[quiz.MQ1]],[[quiz.MQ2]])*([[quiz.extension]]-10)/100, [[quiz.MQ0]])

Walking through:
 # The if statement checks if there is a score for [[quiz.extension]]; if not, then the score for quiz.MQ0 is assigned without any additional adjustments.
 # If there is a score for [[quiz.extension]], then the score for quiz.MQ1 or quiz.MQ2 will be taken, the other quiz having an empty value due to the quiz restrictions.
 # The factor ([[quiz.extension]]-10)/100 sets the late penalty; the "10" needs to be subtracted as a multiple choice question in a quiz assignment requires at least one answer to be marked as 100%.

-Cheers. Greg R.
